ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned what a narrative was! I learned so many elements of craft that I hadn't known before. Professor Sexton's Masterclass book was incredibly helpful in writing stories, and learning what makes readers continue to read. Also, the syllabus was to die for.

I learned so much in this class on the art of crafting fiction! I learned the specific tools to write a compelling short-story, and how these skills are explicitly different than one that we'd learn in a literature class where we'd spend most of our time analyzing pieces of writing.
Learning the craft of fiction writing, how to Critically analyze fiction writing structure and form.

Narrative structure, elements of a story, craft of writing, literally every basic tool you need to write fiction. By the end of this class, I knew how to recognize the elements of a story an craft my own
I learned the most fundamental elements of fiction writing, and in particular the structure of a short story.
Learned how to write a good piece of story. The machine of reading as Adam calls it. Really helpful
Learned a lot about fiction writing! Both my reading published authors and discussing their work in class, and by workshopping your peers work!
I learned the inner workings of what makes a story tick! This class grew my imagination and my appreciation of fiction.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Loved the time spent on craft, helping us all really break down the elements of POV, plot, characterization, description. I learned so much. Also loved the chance to read everyone's writing.
Possible improvement: more writing earlier on? I think you really start to integrate the craft lessons when you practice them yourself, so maybe weekly writing assignments to really experiment with these craft elements ourselves.

There are no weaknesses! The strength was definitely Professor Sexton, and his ability to have fun with students in class and give constructive feedback that didn't demotivate the writer. He pushes students to be bold with their writing, while also giving explicit improvements to give structure to the often arbitrary art of writing.

Strengths: workshop style discussion of stories, short writing assignments that teach you different skills, feedback on writing, several really engaging assigned readings
Weakness: Some of the assigned readings were a bit boring but this was the minority. Feedback could have been received a little quicker, and honestly I would have enjoyed a couple more short writing prompts (perhaps optional ungraded ones even)
It was fun to discuss the readings in class, and have the entire second half of the course (post spring break) solely dedicated to the workshopping of short stories.
An amazing class, really interesting discussions. I think some in class sharing would have been more helpful earlier on in the semester

Strengths: workshop style, attention on craft in discussions

Weaknesses: could be nice to have more writing assignments
We read great books and short stories in the course!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Definitely. I loved the class, Professor Sexton created such a fun and warm community in the classroom. I got to read amazing fiction and also wrote a story of my own that I'm proud of!
YES! One of the best classes I've taken at Yale. Anyone that wants to improve their writing should take this course.

yes! I would definitely recommend this course to any Yale student! The short stories are so fun, and I looked forward to meeting with the class every week. It was such a blessing to see the stories that students were interested in writing, and everyone's unconditional support for each other was so beautiful to see.
Yes, the professor is wonderful and the class size allows for wonderful conversation.

Absolutely - if you have even a passing interesting in writing fiction and understanding how stories work, you should take this class. Prof Sexton is hilarious, incredibly well-read, empathetic, and a great teacher. You will improve as a writer and learn how to write good, readable fiction. The worst case scenario is that you have a fun semester reading the stories assigned for the class and written by your classmates
Yes, if you're interested in reading fiction from a writer's perspective and if you'd like to try your hand at writing stories yourself!
Yes!
Definitely! Its exactly what it sounds like so if that is interesting to you, then yes! Also Professor Sexton has a great workshop style.
Yes, absolutely, if you have an interest in writing fiction. Either way, though, take the course to learn from Professor Sexton. He is amazing.
